turns.speaker: KNIGHT
turns.text: Friend of yours?

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: Of sorts.

turns.speaker: KNIGHT
turns.text: I do hope she enjoys a good show.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: Run!

turns.speaker: KNIGHT
turns.text: MACLEOD!

turns.speaker: KNIGHT
turns.text: You disappoint me.  I thought you'd finally gotten over that sort of thing.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: Leave her out of this.

turns.speaker: KNIGHT
turns.text: As you wish.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: What's the point?

turns.speaker: KNIGHT
turns.text: This isn't done.  Get up.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: What's the point!  You have me, finish it!

turns.speaker: KNIGHT
turns.text: I have waited forever for this. You will not cheapen it, little boy.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: Tradition.

turns.speaker: KNIGHT
turns.text: It's all we have.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: Go to hell.

turns.speaker: KNIGHT
turns.text: Perhaps Miss Cartwright would like to play.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: Leave her alone.

turns.speaker: KNIGHT
turns.text: Get up.

turns.speaker: KNIGHT'S VOICE
turns.text: We have some unfinished business.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: Are you here?

turns.speaker: KNIGHT'S VOICE
turns.text: I want you to come to me.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: And if I refuse?

turns.speaker: KNIGHT'S VOICE
turns.text: Give me an address where I can forward Miss Cart- wright's head.

turns.speaker: KNIGHT'S VOICE
turns.text: Yes laddie, I have her.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: Should I care?

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: This your present address?

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: Mr.-  Taupin, what were you doing in that alley?

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: I was walking by when I heard a shout.  Your men came right after.

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: Did you know the victim?

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: His name was Iman Fasil if that jogs your memory.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: It doesn't.

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: He was carrying a Syrian passport and had been in the country less than a week.

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: Two days ago a Bulgarian national was murdered the same way.  He'd also been in the country less than a week.  What is your citizenship?

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: American.

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: Do you make a habit of hanging out in that neigh- borhood at night?

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: What are you getting at?

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: Let's just say that in my years with this department I've seen more than one well dressed business man look for a hand job on 14th Street.

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: What were _you_ looking for?

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: That's none of your business.

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: You're wrong.

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: Do you know what this is?

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: I presume it's a sword.

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: A claymore to be exact.  You wouldn't know anything about it would you?

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: Your murder weapon?

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: It was covered with Mr. Fasil's fingerprints, but none of his blood.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: A mystery.

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: For the moment.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: My condolences.

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: Where were you Tuesday night?

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: Home.

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: A neighbor saw your car leave.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: He's mistaken.

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: Look, I don't know what the hell you're up to, but I think I've got a pretty good idea.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: Do you?

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: All I need is time.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: I've got all the time in the world.  Except right now.  If you will excuse me, Lieutenant.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Ah Steven, it is good to see you.

turns.speaker: TRAVELLER
turns.text: I only just heard of Conor.  I came up from Catroch as soon as I could.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: You're a kind man to be sure.

turns.speaker: TRAVELLER
turns.text: I thought it only proper to pay me last respects to the family.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Steven, Conor didn't die.

turns.speaker: TRAVELLER
turns.text: But I had heard his wounds were mortal.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: They were Steven, they were.  It's been a miracle it has.  He lasted right through and healed.  No one in the village has ever seen anything like it.  Ever.

turns.speaker: MR. NORTH
turns.text: When your father died I saw to it that the grounds were kept up.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: The money in the estate was enough to cover your costs?

turns.speaker: MR. NORTH
turns.text: Oh yes, more than enough.

turns.speaker: MR. NORTH
turns.text: You're one of William's kids, huh?

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: His only kid.

turns.speaker: MR. NORTH
turns.text: Sure take after him.  Never seen a father and son look more alike.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: We were very close.

turns.speaker: MR. NORTH
turns.text: The resemblance is amazing.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: When may I expect the cleaners?

turns.speaker: MR. NORTH
turns.text: I'll send them right up.

turns.speaker: MR. NORTH
turns.text: Morning Mr. North

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: Same.

turns.speaker: MR. NORTH
turns.text: Such a pretty day.  If I live to be 90 I'll never tire of mornings like this.  Mind you I'm 74 now.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: MR. NORTH
turns.text: Yes sir.  When you get older your priorities change.  It's the simple things that count.  Without them growing old can be a very lonely thing.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: I'm sure that's true.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: Nothing to be sorry about.

turns.speaker: MR. NORTH
turns.text: Just your pappy scared some.

turns.speaker: MURPHY
turns.text: Hello, Harvard! Got anything new on the hanging?

turns.speaker: BENSINGER
turns.text: Why don't you fellows get your own news?

turns.speaker: MURPHY
turns.text: This is Murphy. More slop on the hanging.

turns.speaker: BENSINGER
turns.text: A double guard's been thrown around the jail, municipal buildings, railroad terminals, and elevated stations to prepare for the expected general uprising of radicals at the hour of execution.

turns.speaker: MURPHY
turns.text: Ready? The Sheriff's just put two hundred more relatives on the payroll to protect the city against the Red Army -- which is leaving Moscow in a couple of minutes.  Up a dime.

turns.speaker: BENSINGER
turns.text: The Sheriff has just received four more letters threatening his life, but he says nothing can interfere with his duty.

turns.speaker: MURPHY
turns.text: And to prove to the voters that the Red Menace is on the level, the Sheriff has written himself four more letters, threatening his life. I know he wrote 'em on account of the misspellings.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Can't you say 'hello' to a fellow?

turns.speaker: BENSINGER
turns.text: Hildy!

turns.speaker: BENSINGER
turns.text: Are you back?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: No, just a farewell appearance, batting for Sweeney. I'm going into business for myself.

turns.speaker: BENSINGER
turns.text: What doing?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: I'm getting married tomorrow.

turns.speaker: BENSINGER
turns.text: Well, congratulations! Good luck!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Who is it?

turns.speaker: BENSINGER
turns.text: What's the idea of locking this?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: That's Bensinger. That's his desk.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Bensinger -- of the Tribune.

turns.speaker: BENSINGER
turns.text: Open this door!

turns.speaker: BENSINGER
turns.text: Ain't you got any more sense than to -- ?  Oh, h-hello, Mr. Burns. Why, quite an honor having you come over here.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Hello, Bensinger.

turns.speaker: BENSINGER
turns.text: Excuse me, I just want to --

turns.speaker: BENSINGER
turns.text: How do you mean?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: I was having a little chat about you just this afternoon -- with our Mister Duffy.

turns.speaker: BENSINGER
turns.text: Nothing -- ah -- detrimental, I hope.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: I should say not! That was one swell story you had in the paper this morning.

turns.speaker: BENSINGER
turns.text: Oh, did you -- care for the poem, Mr. Burns?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: The poem?... The poem was great!

turns.speaker: BENSINGER
turns.text: Remember the ending?  " -- and all is well, outside his cell, But in his heart he hears the hangman Calling and the gallows falling And his white-haired mother's tears..."

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Heartbreaking! How would you like to work for me?

turns.speaker: BENSINGER
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Duffy! I'm sending Bensinger over to see you.  Mervyn, isn't it?

turns.speaker: BENSINGER
turns.text: No. Roy. Roy V.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Of course!  Roy Bensinger, the poet. Of course you wouldn't know! You probably never heard of Shakespeare, either! Put Mr. Bensinger right on the staff.  How much are you getting on the Tribune, Roy?

turns.speaker: BENSINGER
turns.text: Seventy-five.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: I'll give you a hundred and a by- line.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Let him have everything he wants.  Now hustle and write me a story from the point of view of the escaped man.  He hides, cowering... Afraid of every light, of every sound... hears footsteps... his heart going like that... And all the time they're closing in... Get the sense of an animal at bay!

turns.speaker: BENSINGER
turns.text: Sort of a Jack London style?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Exactly!

turns.speaker: BENSINGER
turns.text: I got my rhyming dictionary in --

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: It doesn't have to rhyme!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: I'll keep you in mind.

turns.speaker: BENSINGER
turns.text: Au revoir, mon capitaine.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Bon jour!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: I won't be more than ten minutes, I promise you.

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: Even ten minutes is a long time to be away from you.

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: I said -- uh -- I said even ten minutes -- is a long time -- to be away from you.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Don't be embarrassed, Bruce. I heard it, but I just wanted to hear it again. I can stand being spoiled a little. The gentleman I'm going to have a chat with did very little spoiling.

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: I'd like to spoil him just once. Sure you don't want me to go in with you?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: My job, Bruce. I started it -- and I'll finish it.

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: I suppose you're right -- but if it gets rough, remember I'm here.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: I'll come a-running, pardner.

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: Oh, it isn't like that.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: It will be perfectly all right, Walter. Mother is coming with us on the train.

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: You know, Hildy, he's not a bad fellow.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: You're so nice, Bruce, you think everybody else is.

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: Oh, he's not the man for you. I can see that. But I sort of like him. Got a lot of charm.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: He comes by it naturally. His grandfather was a snake.

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: If anybody had told me I'd be sitting at lunch with him -- but he swept me right off my feet.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: That's what he did to me. Swept me right off my feet -- and left me lying on the floor.

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: Too hot?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: No. It's strong.  But I like it that way.

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: Say, what's happened to Burns? He looks sunk, doesn't he?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: He certainly -- hic -- does!

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: I don't use my wife for business purposes, Mr. Burns!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Wait a minute, Bruce. What's commission on a $100,000.00 policy?

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: Well, at his age, twenty payment life, a little over a thousand dollars.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: And what's the matter with a thousand dollars?

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: But --

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: According to the budget, we laid out that's more than our food bill for a whole year. Listen, Bruce, I don't want Walter Burns to use me, but I'm perfectly willing to use him. How long will it take to get him examined?

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: I could get a company doctor in twenty minutes.

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: About twenty-five hundred dollars.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Better make that a certified check, Walter.

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: All right, dear.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Wait a minute, Bruce. Have you got that money?

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: The five hundred? Sure.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: On second thought, would you let me have it? I'll get the tickets.

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: But --

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Believe me, Bruce, I know what I'm doing. He'd get you in a crap game --

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: But I don't gamble, Hilda!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: I know a lot of men who didn't do anything till they met Walter Burns. Please, dear.

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: All right.  One -- two -- three -- four -- five. Five hundred. Be careful, honey.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: I'll be careful, darling. You be, please.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Hildy Johnson... Oh, hello, Bruce. Have you got it? Is it certified?

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: Certified and everything. Got it right here in my wallet... What? No, he's not here -- I'm in a phone booth.

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: All right. I've done it. Now, are you satisfied?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Fine. And here's a kiss for you.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: What's the matter?

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: I lost my wallet.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: The check, Bruce!

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: That's right here. Gee, it was lucky your telling me about that old newspaper superstition.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Yes, wasn't it?

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: I can't imagine who did it. I can't think of any enemies I have.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: I'm sure you haven't any.

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: For a minute, I thought maybe Walter Burns was at the back of it. But then I realized he couldn't have been.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Oh, no. How could you ever think of such a thing?

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: Oh, I realized right away. He's really a very nice fellow, Hildy -- I found that out.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Yes, he is... Look, Bruce, we're taking that next train -- and when I say next train, this time I mean it!

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: Did you finish the interview?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: The Criminal Courts Building.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: No -- but I'm sure it'll be all right with Walter.

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: But, gee, Hildy -- he gave us that insurance business -- and you promised --

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Well, the story's practically finished. I'll just go upstairs and send it over with a messenger.

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: Hildy!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Hello, Bruce...

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: BRUCE!! How'd you get out?

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: Not through any help of yours, Hildy.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Bruce, I know, but I was in the biggest jam --

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: I waited and waited and then I had an idea and wired Albany to send me a hundred dollars so I could get out on bail...  I don't know what they'll think -- they sent it to the police station!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: We'll explain the whole thing to them.

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: I know I got you into this, Hildy, but it does seem to me that you can't care much for me if you're willing to let me stay locked up for two hours.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Bruce, you know I'm mad about you and stop talking like that.  Walter!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Oh, she was here.

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: Where'd she go?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Out some place.

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: Hildy! Where's mother?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Oh -- mother -- she -- I don't know where she went.

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: Did you give her the money?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: No, I was going to give it to her -- but she left hurriedly.

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: Then suppose you give me the money. Four hundred and fifty dollars.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Oh, yes. Here it is.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Here it is, Bruce. One -- two -- three -- four hundred -- and fifty dollars.

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Just a second, Walter. Here, Bruce, here's the check... And, oh, Bruce, here's your wallet. I got it back.

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: You got it back, eh? There's something funny going on around here.

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: I'm taking the nine o'clock train, Hildy. And you can meet us at the station.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Fine.

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: Mr. Burns --

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: I've just told you I was busy with Mr. Bruce Baldwin!

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: I'm Bruce Baldwin!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: You're Bruce Baldwin?

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: Yes!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Then who are you?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: This is a pleasure, Mr. Baldwin, and I'm sorry about the mistake.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Oh, I thought there was something funny... You see, Bruce, you don't mind if I call you Bruce, do you? After all, we're practically related --

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: Mr. -- well -- no -- no -- not at all.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: You see, my wife -- I mean, your wife -- that is, I mean Hildy -- had led me to expect that she was marrying a much older man.

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: But I see, she didn't mean old in years. You always carry an umbrella, Bruce?

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: Well, er -- it looked a little cloudy this morning.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: That's right. -- Rubbers, too, I hope? A man ought to be prepared for any emergency.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Attaboy!  Come on, Bruce.

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: Where are we going?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Where are we going? I'm going to buy you two lunch -- didn't Hildy tell you?

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: No -- she didn't.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Just wanted to surprise you, I guess.  Down!  After you, Bruce!  Come on, Hildy, my treat!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Well, so you're getting married tomorrow, eh? How does it feel, Bruce?

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: Feels awful good. Yes, sir -- we're taking the four o'clock train to Albany and tomorrow we'll be married.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Taking the train today -- and being married tomorrow?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Mother? But your mother --

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: No. My mother.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Oh. Your mother -- well, of course, that relieves my mind.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: I know I wasn't a good husband, Hildy, but you can always count on me.

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: I don't think she'll need you very much -- I aim to do most of the protecting myself.

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: Well, I'll try to give her one.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: I know you will, Bruce. Are you going to live with your mother?

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: Just for the first year.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: That'll be nice. A home with mother. A real honeymoon. In Albany, too. Ow!

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: Mighty nice little town, Albany. They've got the State Capitol there, you know.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Yes, I know...  Hildy, will you ever forget the night you brought the Governor back to your hotel room and found me taking a bath? She didn't even know I was in town...

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: How's business, Bruce?

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: Well, Albany's a mighty good insurance town. Most people there take it out pretty early in life.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: I don't blame them.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: I sometimes wish I'd taken out insurance -- but, of course, now it doesn't matter. Still, I suppose it would have been the smart thing to do.

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: Well, I honestly feel that way. I figure I'm in one line of business that really helps people. Of course, we don't help you much when you're alive -- but afterward -- that's what counts.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: I see what you mean.

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: Anything the matter?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Just Sweeney again. One of my best reporters.

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: Just what is the lowdown on Williams?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: It's simple. A poor little dope who lost his job went berserk and shot a cop who was coming after him to quiet him down.

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: Are you sure Williams is not all there?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: All you've got to do is talk to him. But the Mayor would hang his own grandmother to be re-elected.

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: But couldn't you show the man wasn't responsible?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: How?

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: How long would the interview take?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Oh -- an hour for the interview. Another hour to write it.

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: We could take the six o'clock train, Hildy. If it would save a man's life.

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: I never knew Hildy to be so determined before.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: You haven't seen anything yet.

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: I don't know. This makes me feel funny.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Why shouldn't I make Hildy my beneficiary? I've got nobody else to leave it to.

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: I feel I ought to take care of her.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Well, you'll take care of her. After all, if that doctor's right, I'm going to live for a long time yet. Look, Bruce, this is a debt of honor. I was a very bad husband: Hildy could have got a lot of alimony if she'd wanted to, but she wouldn't take any. She had it coming to her, but she was too independent.

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: Well, I'm independent, too.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Figure it this way: I ought to be good for twenty-five years. By that time, you'll probably have made enough so that the money won't mean anything. But suppose you haven't made good -- don't you think Hildy's entitled to a quiet old age without any worries?

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: Well, of course, if you put it that way.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: And remember this, Bruce! I love her, too.

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: I'm beginning to realize that.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: And the beauty of it is she'll never have to know 'till I've passed on. Maybe she'll think kindly of me --- after I'm gone.

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: Gee, you almost make me feel like a heel -- coming between you.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: No, Bruce, you didn't come between us. It was all over for her before you came on the scene. For me -- it'll never be over.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Well, Bruce, here you are -- certified and everything.

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: Certified! I'm afraid Hildy'd feel ashamed to think she hadn't trusted you.

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: Well, she'll know some day.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: That's all I ask. Oh, wait a minute.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Don't want to forget this, you know. Might start to rain again.

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: Thanks. I'll phone Hildy right away to get that story.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Well, anyway, I know Hildy's getting a good man.

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: Thanks a lot.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Well, I got to get back. You can find your way out, can't you?

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: Oh, sure.  Well, thanks for everything.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Don't thank me. I should thank you. So long.

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: So long.

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: Hildy!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: What the devil do you want? Listen, Bruce, you can't come in here now! We're busy!  Where you been, Duffy? Stick around! What? What Chinese earthquake? The deuce with it... what's that?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: No -- I was just talking to one of the guys at the office.

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: Oh.  I wonder what's keeping mother? She was supposed to come down and get you.

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: And I'll take that certified check, too. I've decided I can handle things around here...

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Come on, Hildy, we've got to keep going! Sorry, Bruce, but --

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: I'll see she's there, Bruce, I promise you.

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: If she's not there, mother and I are leaving anyhow!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: I know how you feel, Bruce, but you've got to forgive her. She's only a woman, after all.

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: Suppose she is -- I have feelings, too! Do you know where I've been for the last couple of hours? Locked up in a police station and she didn't move to do anything about it.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Ts! Ts! Ts!

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: And now I don't know where my mother is. She may be lost.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: I'll find her, Bruce, if I have to put every detective in the city on the job. Tell you what -- go over to the Missing Persons Bureau and describe your mother. What does she look like?

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: She's -- well, she's very motherly. That's about the best description I know.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: That's the kind of stuff they want!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Oh, Bruce, let me see that money Hildy gave you.

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: The money? Why?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: There's a lot of counterfeit big bills going around.

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: Gee! Take a look, will you?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Oh, this is all right, Bruce. I just wanted to be sure.

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: Say, I want to be sure, too!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Who do you think you are, breaking in here like this?

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: You can't bluff me, Burns. I don't care who you are or what paper you're editor of.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: If you've any accusations to make, Hartman, make them in the proper manner. Otherwise, I'll have to ask you to get out.

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: You'll ask me to what?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Get out!

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: Close that door. Don't let anybody in or out.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: I can explain that, Hartman. When Hildy told me she wanted to interview Earl Williams I thought it might be dangerous and I gave her a gun to defend herself.

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: Oh, you did! Well, that's very, very interesting. This happens to be the gun that Earl Williams shot his way out with!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: You're barking up the wrong tree, Hartman.

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: I'll give you three minutes to tell me where he is.

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: No? Well --  Johnson, you're under arrest.  You, too, Burns.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Who's under arrest? You pimple-headed, square-toed spy -- do you realize what you're doing?

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: I'll show you what I'm doing. Burns, you're guilty of obstructing justice and so is the Morning Post. I'm going to see that the Post is fined ten thousand dollars for this.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: You'll see nothing of the kind, Sheriff.

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: We'll just start by impounding the Post property.  Is that your desk?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Hartman, if you take this desk out of this building, I'll put you behind bars.

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: You will, eh? Well, we'll see about that.  All right, boys. Take it.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: I'm warning you -- it'll be a Federal offense.  And you'll be an accessory!

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: We'll take a chance on that, Burns.  Go ahead, boys.

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: What about this, Burns? Kidnapping, eh?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Oh, trying to frame me, eh! I never saw this woman before in my life!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Call Duffy!

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: No, you don't!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Do you want to get us scooped?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: You're going to be in office for exactly two days more and then we're pulling your nose out of the feed bag.

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: Give me the District Attorney's office.  I'll tell you what you'll be doing -- making brooms in the State penitentiary.  Hello, D'Arrasty! This is Hartwell. Come over to my office, will you? I've just arrested a couple of important birds and I want to take their confessions.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: What's this?

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: Get out of here, you!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Does it? You forget the power that always watches over the Morning Post.

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: Your luck's not with you now!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Duffy! Get Liebowitz!

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: All the lawyers in the world aren't going to help you!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: This is the Morning Post you're talking to!

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: The power of the press, huh!

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: That's absurd on the face of it, Mr. Burns! He's talking like a child.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Out of the mouths of babes.

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: He's insane or drunk or something. Why, if this unfortunate man, Williams, has really been reprieved, I personally am tickled to death. Aren't you, Pete?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Save that for the Tribune.

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: What did you say your name was -- Pinkus?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: What do you want?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Why, I'm surprised, Mr. Burns. That's no way to talk to your wife -- even if she's no longer your wife.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Hello, Hildy!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Hello, Walter.  Hi, Louie -- how's the slotmachine king?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: How long is what?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: You know what. How long since we've seen each other?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Let's see. I was in Reno six weeks -- then Bermuda... Oh, about four months, I guess. Seems like yesterday to me.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Maybe it was yesterday. Been seeing me in your dreams?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: No -- Mama doesn't dream about you any more, Walter. You wouldn't know the old girl now.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Oh, yes I would. I'd know you any time --

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: You're repeating yourself! That's the speech you made the night you proposed.  "-- any time -- any place -- anywhere!"

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: I notice you still remember it.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: I'll always remember it. If I hadn't remembered it, I wouldn't have divorced you.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: You know, Hildy, I sort of wish you hadn't done it.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Done what?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Divorced me. It sort of makes a fellow lose faith in himself. It almost gives him a feeling he wasn't wanted.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Holy mackerel! Look, Walter, that's what divorces are for.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Nonsense. You've got the old-fashioned idea that divorces are something that last forever -- till 'death us do part'. Why, a divorce doesn't mean anything today. It's only a few words mumbled over you by a judge. We've got something between us nothing can change.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: I suppose that's true in a way. I am fond of you, Walter. I often wish you weren't such a stinker.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Now, that's a nice thing to say.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Well, why did you promise me you wouldn't fight the divorce and then try and gum up the whole works?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Well, I meant to let you go -- but, you know, you never miss the water till the well runs dry.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: A fellow your age, hiring an airplane to write:  'Hildy: Don't be hasty -- remember my dimple. Walter.! It held things up twenty minutes while the Judge ran out to watch it.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Well, I don't want to brag, but I've still got the dimple -- and in the same place -- I just acted like any husband who doesn't want to see his home broken up.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: What home?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Was it my fault? Did I know that coal mine was going to have another cave-in? I meant to be with you on our honeymoon, Hildy -- honest I did.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: All I know is that instead of two weeks in Atlantic City with my bridegroom, I spent two weeks in a coal mine with John Kruptzky -- age sixty-three -- getting food and air out of a tube! You don't deny that. Do you?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Deny it! I'm proud of it! We beat the whole country on that story.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Well, suppose we did? That isn't what I got married for. What's the good of -- Look, Walter, I came up here to tell you that you'll have to stop phoning me a dozen times a day -- sending twenty telegrams -- all the rest of it, because I'm --

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Let's not fight, Hildy. Tell you what. You come back to work on the paper and if we find we can't get along in a friendly way, we'll get married again.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: What?!!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: I haven't any hard feelings.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Walter, you're wonderful in a loathesome sort of way. Now, would you mind keeping quiet long enough for me to tell you what I came up here for?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Sure, come on. We'll have some lunch and you can tell me everything.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: I have a lunch date. I just want --

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: You can break it, can't you?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: No, I can't.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Sure you can. Come on.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Don't tell me what to do! We're divorced -- I'm a free woman. You're not my husband and you're not my boss! And what's more, you're not going to be my boss.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: What do you mean by that?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Just what I said. That's what I --

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: You mean you're not coming back to work here?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: That's the first time you've been right today. That's what I --

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: You've had a better offer, eh?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: You bet I've got a better offer.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Well, go on and take it. Work for somebody else! That's the gratitude I get for --

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: I know, Walter, but I --

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: What were you when you came here five years ago? A little college girl from a School of Journalism! I took a little doll-faced mugg --

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: You wouldn't have taken me if I hadn't been doll-faced!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Why should I? I thought it would be a novelty to have a face around here a man could look at without shuddering.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Listen, Walter --

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: I made a great reporter out of you, Hildy, but you won't be half as good on any other paper, and you know it. You need me and I need you -- and the paper needs both of us.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Well, the paper'll have to learn to do without me. And so will you. It just didn't work out, Walter.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: It would have worked if you'd been satisfied with just being editor and reporter. But no! You had to marry me and spoil everything.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: I wasn't satisfied! I suppose I proposed to you!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Well, you practically did! Making goo-goo eyes at me for two years till I broke down. And I still claim I was tight the night I proposed. If you'd been a gentleman you'd have forgotten all about it. But not you!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: You -- you --
